DOC.TEXT: Stock prices drifted lower today, registering no strong reaction to the U.S. military action in Panama. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 10.67 to 2,684.94 by 3 p.m. on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 9 to 8 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 690 up, 779 down and 492 unchanged. Analysts said investors were cautiously watching the situation in Panama, but apparently not viewing it as any cause to make big changes in their strategies. They noted that the prospective economic effects of the confrontation, if any, remained unclear. At the same time, brokers said, stock traders appeared to draw only brief encouragement from an upward revision in the latest government figures on economic growth. The Commerce Department said the gross national product grew at a 3.0 percent annual rate, after adjustment for inflation, in the third quarter of the year, up from a previous estimate of 2.7 percent. Economists' projections remained gloomy, however, for the results to be posted in the fourth quarter and the early stages of 1990. Walt Disney fell 10 to 113] in selling attributed to recession worries and a more wary appraisal by some analysts of the company's earnings outlook. Stride Rite dropped 4[ to 23[. The company said its earnings for this year and next are likely to come in on the low side of estimates. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dipped .17 to 189.23. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .09 at 367.86. Volume on the Big Board came to 149.73 million shares with an hour to go.
